1.content:
Varja Wayne sacrificed her usual hour-long grooming routine in the morning just to write out her latest dream. The documenting of her dreams had become quite elaborate in the last five months. She used her insights from the dream interpretations to map out her near-future choices. A diagnosis of brain cancer at the very beginning of the year had crushed a small fistful of dreams before her, so she had become all the more willing to note what her subconscious brought forth.

May 19, 2008
I have been piloting a small, ancient brig on calm open waters. On the ship I have no personal life. Yet, there is a feeling that I am somehow connected to a person on shore. I endure pain at the very crown of my head when I try to acknowledge this connection. Suddenly a storm fills the sky and sea around me. All colors fade into the shadows of the blue-grey horizon. I have the instinct to turn the bow of my ship into the very force of the growing waves. I am aware of the real possibility of any moment crashing and dying upon sharp rocks near a choppy harbor even if everything is done "right." The connection remains despite my fears and the sense of being off-course.

There is a reassuring voice, booming with the wind, "There is only where I am, and the way to me cannot be lost. You may simply be keeping yourself out of view."

Oh, so this is my fault now, huh? Will a mutiny at the core of my own heart defeat my desire to keep going?

I must be treasure-hunting; looking for a miracle. There is a metamorphosis possible when I simply hold my hand out. It is more than an invitation - it is a fearful pleading when the monster is creeping ever closer. What happens when I cannot see either it, or you approach to pull me to safety? If I do not have confidence in the voice which is leading me, and whether we are communicating on the most basic level, so how can I be anything but already across the threshold of Death?

More than once I have drowned in a dream , and I wonder if this will be how I ultimately leave my body behind. And I tremble that the thought of experiencing a different body’s lasting hug around my soul.

I dream, but live my life with honor in not moving on the desire to try having control our such details.
1.title: Storm Warning

11.content:
You may be right that I have not given enough details at this point. Your comment at least made me go back and re-read it. But the beauty of an interactive is that YOU can add what you feel it needs. Your own comment good have been the start of the thread in which it is the caregiver reading the dream journal entry. It might have read something like this:

Maggie Letren smoothed the bangs on Varja's sweat-streaked forehead. She thought to herself, this position isn't going to last the month I'd hoped it would. Maggie was brought in for Varja's hospice just four days earlier. Most of those days, Varja was happy to have the company and talk. A few other times, Varja's state was close to comatose. It was plain that Varja was actively dying, but there was some stubborn hanging on to be found in the writing that she continued to do in this journal. Varja directly asked Maggie's opinion just the night before.

"It's a very interesting story, I will give you that. Except, Varja dear, it's just a little hard to follow because {I hate to admit it} of the words you used. I don't understand them. I think if you made the writing easier or gave some more insight into the Varja I didn't know a week ago. That's the life you're really trying to "document," as you say. Then, for those that will be left behind when you are gone...it would be easier for them to add some meaning onto it. I mean, why you'd be spending you time and energy doing it."

She has her clear moments. Still writing out things for me to read, for when the fever takes her out. Is that sane?.

112.content:
Hospice worker Letrell only slightly jolts when the catheter alarm makes its insistent whine. She stands steady and and reaches across Varja's bed to disengage the audio alarm. She kneels down to do the most common function of her job -- the toileting. Because it is so mundane to her now, her mind has the opportunity to wander.

This one seems like a fighter, although no doctor orders Hospice for one who could recover. She's sweet to want to clear her mind and conscience, but it is a shame the family she seems to be fighting for is around so little? Is death after a long battle just? Is it divinely compassionate? I guess with those kind of questions in me, I can appreciate my own capacity to show compassion. I'll leave the church questions to churchier folk.

1122.content:
Maggie Letren--or Letrell, as Varja likes to call her for some reason--wondered about the life of this rather mysterious woman for whom she was now caring.

Nobody ever came to see her.

Why?

Had there been some sort of a family rift?

or

Did her loved ones either live too far away or else had difficulties of their own that kept them away?

Varja was an open book about some things, but, when it came to her loved ones, she would change the subject if Letrell questioned her too much.

Yet, she seemed to be writing in this journal for somebody instead of merely writing for herself.

Three days later, Varja gave Letrell a note with instructions to call somebody named Margaret Letrell and let her know that she needed to get over to see her very soon, as it was almost time.

At that point, Varja slipped into a coma but was still very much alive in all other ways.

She was still in the coma when Margaret arrived a day later...

12.content:
Knowing the counselor will remind me to honor my path, I must release attachments and control. Yet it is difficult to stay focused on a goal to lessen control when that is all I have done with my life. That thought of what a life after death experience will be -- imagining my soul at some point having a vehicle to steer again -- that's already what I've made up my mind it may be like. Again, it is craving control.

Why is this me? It demands this outcome, my driving force. I wonder for how long it has quested in this fashion. I try not to attach god or bad to it. Then, another thought -- what if I were to deny what I believe.

How does the core of me react if I say to it, "No, this is it. The end of this body will be the end -- there is nothing more." Would that be such a hard thing to accept?

13.content:
Patricia exits the bus not more than five minutes after that with the story she was reading still haunting her.

She had found this book at a yard sale just a couple of days before and thought that it would be something good to read while going to and from the fast-food establishment where she worked.

She wasn't the fastest reader in the world, so she had only managed to read a little of it before it was time to get out and start asking customers, "Do you want fries with that?"

She decided that she would wait until she returned home to read the book so that she could really get into it without any distractions.

She leaves the bus.

Another Option Explaining This Besides Time Travel
131.content:
Patricia knew she must have gotten off at the wrong stop because she not only didn't see the fast-food restaurant but, also, the entire area looked different.

Where was she anyway?

She saw an older school building in front of her. She had remembered being told that a school had once stood on the block that now contained her workplace and some other businesses, and this school looked like the one in a photograph that the person had shown her--but how could that be!?!

She would just have to find out where she was and get back to where she was supposed to be before she ended up losing her job.

1311.content:
She saw the street signs--and, according to them, she should have been right where she was supposed to be--so why was she looking at an old school?

She had heard of time-travel before but had never really believed it, but this is what this had to be. There was no other explanation for it.

Was there?

13111.author_name: AJ wants U 2 meet The CanMan!
choices: Visiting Baby Varja
13111.content:
Patricia wondered what time it was--not to mention what year it was!

She soon got an approximate time when the bell rang and kids spilled out onto the playground for recess.

Three girls--all around the age of twelve, give or take--sat down under a tree and began to talk.

"So, how does it feel to be an aunt?" one tall, thin girl with long, red hair who was wearing a flower-print dress that went down to just above her sandal-clad feet asked a short, chubby girl with short, curly, dishwater-blonde hair.

"Wonderful!! You should see my new niece! She's so adorable!"

"Do you have pictures?" the third girl whose chestnut-color hair was done in two ponytails (one on each side of her head) asked.

"Of course not! She was just born! My mom took some pictures--this IS her first grandchild--but it will take several days for the roll to be developed, once she gets it to the photo store. Hey! You want to go to the hospital during visiting hours and get a look at her?"

The other two girls replied in excited affirmation.

"I thought that going to see The Osmond Brothers and getting to meet them after the show was the most exciting thing that could ever happen to me, but being an aunt is ten times more exciting than that--and that's pretty exciting, as I would love to marry Donny when I grow up. He has to marry somebody, you know!"

"I'd rather marry Michael Jackson!" the curly-haired girl said. "Do you know that we have the same birthday? I mean, the same year and everything!"

"Sure, we know," the girl with the ponytails replied with a giggle. "This is about the millionth time you told us this!"

"You can't marry Michael Jackson!"

"Who invited you and why not?" the curly-haired girl addressed the freckle-faced boy who seemed to have appeared out of nowhere.

"He's the wrong color for you! What would people say?"

"They'd say we made an adorable couple--so there! The world is changing, Randy. I bet we'll even have a Black President in our lifetime!"

"Aw, you're weird, Maggie! I think you need to see one of those psychiatrists!" Randy turned to a couple of near-by boys. "Baby Elephant thinks that Michael Jackson is going to be the first Black President. . ."

"I didn't say that. . ."

"Well! You said something like that. Anyway, you're not gonna marry Michael Jackson, and it will be at least 100 more years before we have anybody but White men even running for President. This country's almost 200 years old, and it hasn't happened yet!"

"Aw, just ignore those guys! They don't know what they're talking about. . ." the girl who had just become an aunt said. "Anyway, my new niece's name is Varja Suzanne Wayne. . ."

Patricia picked up her book and looked at the name of the main character: Varja Wayne

The hospice care worker's name was Maggie--just like the girl who was dreaming of marrying Michael Jackson.

Was this a dream or what?

Not only had she been transported back in time to around what. . .1970?. . .but she was also living inside of a book that was supposed to be fiction. Or was it?

She looked at who had written the book and realized that--though it was written as a story--it was actually real, as the author of it was Maggie Letren, the hospice worker.

She looked at the dedication and had to smile, as it was dedicated to her husband and best friend, Randy.

Patricia wasn't sure if she would still find her job waiting for her when she returned from wherever this was she had been sent, but she wasn't going to worry about that. She was just going to enjoy this experience for as long as it lasted.

She knew that there was only one hospital in town, so that's where the girls would be going to later that evening. She decided to sit on a bench in the park across from the hospital and read more of the book.

She would only read it so far, though, because she didn't want to know if Varja ended up dying or if some miracle happened and she survived.

She just wanted to share in the joy and excitement that these girls were feeling at the moment.
13111.title: It Was Time Travel All Right!
